title: The most popular fact checks of September
subtitle: Our monthly round-up of the most widely read fact checks is topped by a controversial one on Carly Fiorina.
author: www.washingtonpost.com
vclaim:
We examined GOP presidential candidate Carly Fiorina only-in-America life story, and found it wanting. But many readers vehemently disagreed with our award of Three Pinocchios—so much so that we published a response. That still didn’t end the complaints.

2: Ben Carson’s claim that ‘we have 10 times more people on welfare’ since the 1960s

GOP presidential hopeful Ben Carson made a series of claims about the ineffectiveness of anti-poverty programs. But his claim that the number of people on “welfare” has grown tenfold is not supported by the numbers. There has been an increase, at a rate that exceeds population growth, but not to the extent claimed by Carson. So he earned Two Pinocchios.

3: Ben Carson’s claim that ‘taqiyya’ encourages Muslims ‘to lie to achieve your goals’

We interviewed experts on Islamic law to see if Carson’s claim had much basis in fact, and concluded he was mouthing a discredited and inaccurate interpretation of a relatively minor section of the Koran. But some readers objected to our sources.

4: For Planned Parenthood abortion stats, ‘3 percent’ and ’94 percent’ are both misleading

This is a rare instance when a fact check in one month continues to be so popular that it also appears on the top-five list the following month. This fact check of two misleading claims about Planned Parenthood was in fourth place in August—and remained in fourth place in September.
